PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Fred Davies
Address: Salt Lake, Sask.
Birthplace: Manchester, England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1883
Where did you set up housekeeping? 15 miles west of Salt Lake, but bought land there.
Where had you been living before that? England, city of Manchester.
For how many people did you prepare meals? There were six in family (4 children).
How far was it to your nearest store? 2 miles.
How often could a visit be made to the store? Not very often, had to walk.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, molasses, and molasses, some rice, some dried apples in string, pearl barley, a little tea (no coffee was sold), dried white beans, baking powder, B.Soda, candles, matches (matches did not use tobacco, plugs and)

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?
In what quantities did you buy it? The Bag.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? In 1893 $4.50.
How much did you use graham flour? None.
Whole wheat flour? Yes.
Was flour milled locally? No, far away? 20 miles. What year? 1890.
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? Sold by the pound.
What other grain products did you use? Rice, oatmeal was parboiled.
Cornmeal? Yes, some. Whole Wheat? Yes, Bread. Farina? Not until about 1904.
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? At times, of course.
How did you grind it? Little hand mills.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? Price in 1934 we bought 8 lbs worth for $1.00.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? From 10 to 25¢ per lb.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? No brand for years, R.J. Dorphum.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 1 liter, you all used 1 pound each, usually 20¢.

At what price? A big lot of 6¢ each for eight dollars, Dorphum.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? In milk for two years.

Did you get butter? Yes, Pound or sacks for 40¢.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes, in lots, how? Usually in frozen water.

Did you make butter? Yes, when the cows gave?

What kind of cheese? Any case, hard mixed with sugar and cream.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Rabbits and P. Chicken ducks.

How did you get fresh meat? Hunted, shot and smoked it.

How often did you get fresh meat? Almost daily, Game, late hops.

How did you preserve meat? Salt and smoked it.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes in 1910.

If so what year was it organized? Around 1905 or 1910, I think.

Did you use game? Constantly.

What kinds? Rabbit, chicken, ducks, pheasant, quail.

For how long? For many years.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Fish in lakes, huge cat.

Did you buy canned fish too high priced, fish very seldom any place.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Any way you could get it.

Kinds? Fresh fish, Pike, perch, lake perch, canned salmon brings the

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes dried Saskatoons
peas? corn? beans? Saskatoons? Yes
other foods? Pumpkins

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1910 to 1913

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? Same

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? Several years later

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Only occasionally

To what extent? From 50 to over a hundred bottles

Did you make your own vinegar? Yes in the very early years, then sold in stores
9. What type of yeast did you use? Royal yeast for years and years

Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes, self rising

Using hops? No, salt rising? Yes, occasionally cheaper

Did you buy baker's powder? Lots of it, baking soda? Yes, strongly preferred it

Grains of barley? Yes, same, did you make your own baking powder? No

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

In 1863, anything you could get but fried swine belly and the grease from pork was a treat. For breakfast:
Dinner, boiled rabbit, and cubes of fat pork, and B Powder dumplings and dessert of more molasses. Butter B Powder turns hard because no butter for several years, some boiled buckwheat, very little sugar, perhaps some dried apples. Some cold beans, possibly some cold boiled pork belly. These times were the painful dishes for poor people and with all these luxuries we never complained. Later when we got a cow or cows, we would milk milk and butter. I recall that the first event, a little Pigeon Chicken saved my life at a crucial time.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in western Canada?

Rabbits, meat, fish. The menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Father & mother, between 40 and 50
Sister II, myself 8, Brother 6, sister 4. We did not celebrate in those days, but I remember my mother cried at the poor dinner we had.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Rabbits saved our lives without them, we children might have gone under. In the following summers we lived better. Black chicken flowers, Black birds and the occasional beaver helped out, but the beaver was an oily thing nauseating meat, it took a strong stomach to handle it, personally I preferred beaver or muskrat.

In 1863, anything you could get but fed scarcely and the grease thrown over a fire. For breakfast, I had breakfast, dinner, boiled rabbit, and cuber of fat pork, and a brown dumpling and dessert of more molasses. Dinner B. B. had two hashpans no butter for several years, some boiled vegetables, very little sugar, perhaps some dried apples. Some cold beans, possibly some cold boiled pork belly. These times were the finest days for poor people and with all these luxuries we were compelled. Later when we got a cow or cows, we could in milk and butter. I myself did the first event, a little brown chicken serving life at a casual time.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

The meals eaten in the earlier years were greatly less edible than present fare, and I have heard men claim that on pioneer food, a man was much better off. Gradually as livestock increased, the standard of living improved until today, we live in luxury. And kings or politicians live on the same foods as the ordinary man's families of today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

These changes have come so gradually that it is impossible to give data. Today our foods are semi-prepared, semi-cooked, less and less cooking is done by all walks of life. Housekeeping is so simplified that there is nothing to it; whereas in the early days you had to hunt and kill before you ate, and live off the land. I was a pioneer, I saw the whole experience of life and death, both plenty and semi-starvation. I would not wish to live it again. Incidentally, the good old days never existed.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Eastern Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

I claim that the mail order stores did much for the people. That the railways gave us good transportation. That the machine companies brought help, but they led us. That the mortgage companies brought capital into a country otherwise valueless, and set the wheels of progress rolling. And Lastly, that churches of all creeds gave comfort to both the living and the dying, and preached the word of God constantly and steadfastly through all the years of war and bloodshed. Amen.

Fred S. Baines.
